facts.text: Father of the appellant owned considerable agricultural property in Pakistan and he with the members of his family moved over to India on partition.
Appellant's father was allotted a considerable extent of land in village Kharar, District Ambala, but the appeal concerns Khasra Nos. 880, 881 and 882.
On December 29, 1955, the Managing Officer allotted Khasra Nos. 880, 881 and 882 to the appellant on quasi-permanent tenure in lieu of his father's unsatisfied claim for allotment.
A sanad was issued to the appellant on December 31, 1955 by the Managing Officer.

When the appellant tried to take possession, disputes were raised by respondent Nos. 4 and 5, who were not displaced persons but claimed possession from a long anterior date and that the property could not be the subject of a valid allotment.
Respondent Nos. 4 and 5 moved the Assistant Settlement Commissioner for cancellation of the allotment.
Assistant Settlement Commissioner cancelled the allotment, finding the land within urban area per r. 2(h) of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules, 1955.
Appellant applied to the Chief Settlement Commissioner in revision and was unsuccessful.
Appellant moved the Punjab High Court by petition under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution, which was dismissed on November 26, 1959.
Appeal to Supreme Court on certificate of fitness under Art. 133 granted by Punjab High Court.
Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules, 1955 published and came into force on May 21, 1955.
Khasra Nos. 880, 881 and 882 included in urban limits on February 10, 1951 by extension of municipal area of Kharar.

legal_issues.text: Whether after the Managing Officer granted a sanad on December 31, 1955 in the name of the President of India, the appellant obtained an indefeasible title to the property that could not be displaced except on grounds contained in the sanad itself even if the order of allotment was set aside on appeal or revision.
Whether rule 2(h) of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules, 1955 was unconstitutional as contravening Art. 14 of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: After the Managing Officer granted a sanad on December 31, 1955 in the name of the President of India, the appellant obtained an indefeasible title to the property and that this title could not be displaced except on grounds contained in the sanad itself even in the event of the order of allotment being set aside on appeal or revision.

Rule 2(h) of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules, 1955 was unconstitutional as contravening Art. 14 of the Constitution and so the original allotment to the appellant must be held to be lawful.

respondent_arguments.text: Respondents Nos. 4 and 5 had been in possession of the property from a long anterior date from which they could not be disturbed and the property could not be the subject of a valid allotment.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: r. 2(h) of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules, 1955

court_reasoning.text: The first contention rejected for reasons stated in Shri Mithoo Shahani and Ors. v. The Union of India and Ors. pronounced on March 10, 1964.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sanad does not confer indefeasible title immune from cancellation on appeal or revision.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 2(h) is valid; no discrimination under Art. 14. Allotment made after rules came into force on an urban area land is invalid. Proviso applies only to prior allotments, using 15 August 1947 urban limits. Prospective operation of rule does not violate Art. 14 as every law has a commencement date.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No substance in argument of discrimination; rule competently made under s.40 of the Act.

holdings.text: Sanad does not confer indefeasible title that cannot be displaced on appeal or revision.
Rule 2(h) of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules, 1955 is constitutional and does not violate Art. 14.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shri Mithoo Shahani and Ors. v. The Union of India and Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Reasons for rejecting contention that sanad confers indefeasible title.

statutes_cited.name: Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Enables Central Government to make rules; rules competently made thereunder.

statutes_cited.name: Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Rules, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines urban area; prohibits allotment of urban land; proviso for prior allotments.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.14 alleged violation; Arts.226/227 for High Court petition; Art.133 for certificate.

outcome.summary: The appeal is dismissed, upholding the High Court's dismissal of the petition under Arts. 226 and 227. The allotment to the appellant of Khasra Nos. 880, 881 and 882, being urban land under r.2(h), was invalidly made after the rules came into force.

key_quotes.text: We have considered this point in Shri Mithoo Shahani and Ors. v. The Union of India and Ors. which was pronounced on March 10, 1964 and for the reasons there stated this submission has to be rejected.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects indefeasible title argument by reference to precedent.

key_quotes.text: We consider that there is no substance in this argument. In fact, we are unable to appreciate the ground on which the contention is being urged.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Every law must have a beginning or time from which it operates, and no rule which seeks to change the law can be held invalid for the mere reason that it effects an alteration in the law.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why prospective operation does not violate Art.14.
